;;阿拉斯加苏厄德的基奈峡湾国家公园。路透社/乔纳森·恩斯特;
;

;阿拉斯加州机构周三起诉拜登政府决定取消该州北坡的石油和天然气租赁，该州北坡是该国最大的原始联邦土地储备之一.

;

;向华盛顿特区联邦法院提起的诉讼对美国内政部 9 月 6 日的;决定废除;阿拉斯加占地 1,900 万英亩（770 万公顷）的北极国家野生动物保护区的七个石油和天然气租约，该地区极易受到气候变化和灰熊和北极熊、驼鹿群和雪鸮的家园。

;

;在租约被取消之前持有租约的阿拉斯加工业发展和出口管理局正在要求美国哥伦比亚特区地方法院恢复它们，认为联邦政府的决定违反了国会在 2017 年税收法案中开放北极进行钻探的明确授权。

;

;“联邦政府决心剥夺阿拉斯加自给自足的能力，我们共和党阿拉斯加州州长迈克·邓利维在一份声明中表示：“我们必须阻止它。

;

;美国内政部没有立即回应置评请求。

;

;取消的租约已被出售。在阿拉斯加官员几十年来努力在保护区进行钻探并提振该州依赖石油的经济之后，特朗普政府的权力日渐衰落。

;

;该国家机构成为大多数项目的唯一竞标者主要石油和天然气公司选择跳过 2020 年出售后的面积，;产生了约 1440 万美元;。

;

;这些收益与 2019 年国会预算办公室的报告相差甚远，该报告估计十年内避难所的两次拍卖可能带来高达 18 亿美元的收益

;

;虽然避难所的沿海平原估计蕴藏着高达 118 亿桶的石油，但它没有道路、已建成的小径或其他基础设施。

;

;这些因素可能引起了人们的兴趣由于总统政府即将发生变化，钻井公司的风险降至最低，此外还有石油市场波动、法律挑战带来的风险以及任何租赁未来的政治不确定性。

;

;另外两家在 2020 年赢得租赁的实体出售在 2022 年撤回其持有的股份。

;

;内政部在 9 月份取消了剩余的七份租约，称前任政府的租约出售“存在严重缺陷”，并且未能考虑石油对气候变化的影响等问题。

;

;该州周三提起的诉讼称，这些担忧并不能证明内政部的举动是合理的，因为 2017 年税法并未赋予该机构通过拒绝发放租约来避免这些影响的自由裁量权.

;根据拜登政府新倡议，美国首架飞往委内瑞拉的驱逐航班于周三降落在加拉加斯，这是更严厉的制裁的一部分在美国与创纪录的非法越境作斗争之际，美国采取了边境执法的方法。

;

;周三早上，在得克萨斯州哈林根的一个机场，巴士将戴上镣铐的委内瑞拉男女扔到停机坪上，他们在那里被搜身并被引导路透社目击者称，他们乘坐的是包机。据美国移民和海关执法局 (ICE) 称，约有 130 名委内瑞拉人被驱逐出境。

;

;美国总统乔·拜登的政府一直在努力应对试图非法越过美墨边境的移民数量创纪录的趋势，这一趋势由于美国制裁加剧了逃离本国经济和政治不稳定的委内瑞拉人急剧增加。

;

;自 2021 年拜登上任以来，已有超过 380,000 名委内瑞拉人非法越过美墨边境被捕。从 2019 财年的约 2,200 人到 2020 财年的 1,200 人。

;

;驱逐出境是在拜登政府上台几周后重新开始的;向在7月31日或之前抵达美国的近50万委内瑞拉人发放了;驱逐救济和工作许可证，理由是“委内瑞拉的不稳定局势加剧，缺乏安全感。 “

;

;美国和委内瑞拉官员;本月早些时候表示; 由于两国之间的外交紧张关系，直接驱逐被搁置多年后将重新启动。

;

;美国边境巡逻队队长贾森·欧文斯在得克萨斯州告诉记者，移民应该通过合法途径进入美国或按计划入境预约接近合法过境点而不是非法过境。

;

;“信息很简单。如果你想来到这个国家，就以正确的方式去做。”欧文斯说。

;

;ICE 高级官员科里·普莱斯 (Corey Price) 表示，该机构的目标是每周向委内瑞拉派遣几架驱逐航班。< /p>;

;周二，委内瑞拉政府及其政治反对派;同意 2024 年总统选举的选举保证;。路透社 ;周三报道;，作为回应，拜登政府计划对委内瑞拉石油和天然气行业提供一些制裁减免。

;

;本月早些时候，移民倡导者批评了加大驱逐力度的举措委内瑞拉。

;

;美国公谊服务委员会科罗拉多州项目主任詹妮弗·派珀称其“极其残忍和致命”，并敦促拜登政府“立即停止将人驱逐到危险地点。”

; Thu, 19 Oct 2023 05:55:03 +0800 Sam Bankman-Fried trial jury sees his profane messages about regulatorshttps://reuters.com/article/usa-bankmanfried/sam-bankman-fried-trial-jury-sees-his-profane-messages-about-regulators-idUSKBN31I233

;

;周三山姆·班克曼·弗里德 (Sam Bankman-Fried) 欺诈案审判中的检方向陪审员展示了一系列亵渎的信息，他认为派出记者抱怨监管机构，挑战 FTX 创始人作为加密货币监管支持者的形象。

;

;陪审团还看到了 Bankman-Fried 向一名记者发送的一条含有脏话的信息。 Twitter 上的加密新闻网站 The Block（该社交媒体平台现称为 X）提到了美国证券交易委员会主席加里·詹斯勒 (Gary Gensler)。

;

;在 10 月 3 日开始的审判中，Bankman-Fried 被指控掠夺数十亿美元。 FTX 客户资金中的美元用于投资、向美国政治竞选活动捐款以及支持他的对冲基金 Alameda Research。检察官表示，他的政治捐款旨在促进有利于加密货币的立法。

;

;这位前亿万富翁对两项欺诈罪和五项共谋罪不认罪。 31 岁的班克曼-弗里德（Bankman-Fried）如果罪名成立，可能面临数十年的监禁。

;

;班克曼-弗里德（Bankman-Fried）的律师曾试图阻止检察官向 Vox 记者介绍这些信息作为证据，认为被告发送了“非-在审判中的争议时间段之后，他说“袖口沉思”，并且这种语言会使陪审团对他产生偏见。

;

;在主张允许陪审团查看这些信息时，检察官丹妮尔·沙逊表示，这些信息是“高度证明”了他当时的真实心态，并指出班克曼-弗里德后来告诉记者，他认为这次谈话没有公开。

;

;Vox 最终;发布了;消息。

;

;Bankman-Fried 写道，他之前支持监管加密货币的言论“只是 PR”，即公共关系。

;

;“这并不反映他当时参与加密货币交易时的诚实意图。辩护律师 Christian Everdell 在陪审团在场外表示，他反对将这些信息作为证据。

;

;泽伦斯基在 Telegram 消息应用程序上写道：“邪恶国家继续使用恐怖手段并对平民发动战争。必须击败俄罗斯恐怖分子。”

;;FTX 前首席执行官 Sam Bankman-Fried 因加密货币交易所破产而面临欺诈指控，他在曼哈顿听证会后离开美国纽约市联邦法院，2023 年 1 月 3 日。路透社/Andrew Kelly/档案照片;
;

;美国法官周三驳回了 Sam Bankman-Fried 律师的反对意见，并允许 FTX 担任陪审员创始人的欺诈审判中看到他在加密货币交易所倒闭几天后向记者发送的一条亵渎信息，抱怨监管机构“让一切变得更糟”。

;

;这是 Bankman-Fried 向记者发送的几条私人信息之一新闻网站 Vox on Twitter（该社交媒体平台现在称为 X）在曼哈顿联邦法院的审判期间辩方试图远离陪审团。

;

;在 10 月 10 日开始的审判中。 3 月 3 日，Bankman-Fried 被指控掠夺 FTX 数十亿美元客户资金进行投资、向美国政治竞选活动捐款以及支持他的对冲基金 Alameda Research。这位前亿万富翁对两项欺诈罪和五项共谋罪不认罪。 31 岁的班克曼-弗里德如果罪名成立，可能会面临数十年的监禁。

;

;班克曼-弗里德的律师曾试图阻止检察官将这些信息作为证据，辩称被告发送了“即兴的沉思” “在审判中有争议的时间段之后，这种语言会让陪审团对他产生偏见。

;

;在其中一条消息中，班克曼-弗里德告诉记者，“去他妈的监管机构”，并很快在另一条消息中补充道消息，“它们让一切变得更糟。”

;

;在主张允许陪审团查看这些消息时，检察官丹妮尔·沙逊表示，这些消息“高度证明”了他当时的真实心态，并指出班克曼-弗里德后来告诉记者，他认为这次谈话没有被记录下来。

;

;Vox 最终;发布了;这些消息。

;

;Bankman-Fried 写道，他之前支持监管的声明加密货币“只是 PR”，意思是公共关系。

;

;辩护律师 Christian Everdell 在陪审团在场外表示，“这并不反映他在与监管机构接触时的诚实尝试”，并反对允许这些信息作为证据。

;

;检察官表示，他们最早可以在 10 月 26 日结束案件。Bankman-Fried 的律师表示，他正在考虑为自己辩护作证。

;抗议者周三在中东各地举行反以色列集会，其中一些人变得暴力，以表达对以色列的愤怒。 ;爆炸;导致以色列一家医院数百名巴勒斯坦人死亡以色列-哈马斯战争期间加沙地带最致命的事件。

;

;以色列军队;shot dead; two Palestinian teenagers near Ramallah in the West Bank during protests against Tuesday's blast at Al-Ahli al-Arabi hospital in Gaza City, Palestinian officials said.< /p>;

;The two sides have blamed each other for the explosion.

;

;In Lebanon, security forces fired tear gas and water canon at protesters who were throwing projectiles as a protest near the US Embassy north of Beirut turned violent, footage by Lebanese broadcaster al-Jadeed showed.

;

;"America is the devil, the real devil, because it supported Israel, and then all the world is blind. You don't see what happened yesterday?" said Lebanese demonstrator Mohammed Taher.

;

;State-sponsored marches were held across Iran, backer of Hamas and Israel's sworn foe, with demonstrators carrying banners that read "Death to America" and "Death to Israel".

;

;"Every drop of blood of Palestinians killed in this war, brings the Zionist regime (Israel) closer to its downfall," Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi said in a televised speech.

;

;Demonstrations were not confined to the Muslim world or the Middle East. Hundreds of Jewish peace activists rallied in Washington calling on the Biden administration and Congress to press for a ceasefire.

;

;Some 200 demonstrators, many from the group Jewish Voice for Peace, filled the ;rotunda of the Cannon House Office Building; near the US Capitol, chanting, "The world is watching." They wore black T-shirts emblazoned with the messages, "Jews Say Cease Fire Now" and "Not in Our Name."

;

;The US Capitol Police said its officers began arresting protesters who refused to comply with orders to disperse. Some 500 other protesters blocked off Independence Avenue outside.

;

;Palestinian officials blamed an Israeli air strike for Tuesday's explosion in northern Gaza. Israel said the blast was caused by a failed rocket launch by the Palestinian Islamic Jihad militant group, which denied blame.

;

;The latest bloodshed enraged a region in crisis since Hamas, which controls the Gaza Strip, carried out a cross-border rampage against communities in southern Israel on Oct. 7 in which 1,400 people were killed and hostages were taken.

;

;More than 3,000 Palestinians have been killed in retaliatory bombing of the crowded coastal enclave by Israel, Gaza health authorities say.

;

;In Iraq, about 300 supporters of Iran-backed Shi'ite militia groups protested near a bridge which leads to the fortified Green Zone, home to the US Embassy and other foreign missions.

;

;"Americans must know that their support to the terrorist Israel will bring them defeat and devastation,” militia member Said Ali Akbar said, waving a Palestinian flag.

;

;In Amman, riot police pushed back thousands of Jordanian protesters planning to march on the heavily fortified Israeli Embassy. Several police were injured in clashes with protesters who torched property near the embassy, police said.

;

;"No Zionist embassy on Arab land," demonstrators chanted in the Jordanian capital after noon prayers.

;

;In Tunis, protesters burned Israeli and American flags and demanded the expulsion of the US and French ambassadors for what they termed their unconditional support for Israel.

;

;"They (Palestinians) have no food or water, and they are getting bombed. This is genocide, not war. This is a crime. We must find a solution," demonstrator Ines Laswed said.

;

;The protesters shouted slogans backing Hamas, including "Revenge ... revenge ... Oh Hamas, bomb Tel Aviv."

;

;In Yemen, thousands marched in the capital Sanaa. Mohammed Ali Al-Rammah of the ruling Houthi movement denounced what he called Israeli lies and hatred.

;

;"We will fight you," he said.

;

;In Beirut's Hezbollah-controlled southern suburbs, thousands of people gathered for a ;protest;, waving Hezbollah, Palestinian and Lebanese flags and chanting, "Death to America".

;

;Senior Hezbollah official Hashem Safieddine told the rally the group was "thousands of times stronger" than before and the US, Israel and "malicious Europeans" should be careful.

;

;Saudi Arabia urged its nationals to leave Lebanon citing "current events" in the south of Lebanon, where Hezbollah has been exchanging fire at the border with Israeli forces.

;

;France's Foreign Ministry said on Wednesday it was advising its citizens against any travel to Lebanon given the security situation, especially at Lebanon's border with Israel.

;

;Security concerns have risen across much of Europe linked to the Israel-Hamas conflict and to attacks by other Islamist groups such as Islamic State (IS). France says 24 of its citizens were among the 1,400 people killed in Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel.

;

;Italy has ;stepped up surveillance,; especially in crowded areas, and increased protection for sites that might be targets for attacks, Interior Minister Matteo Piantedosi said.

;Former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro's legal jeopardy has mounted since he narrowly lost last year's presidential election to leftist President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, barring him from upcoming elections and raising the prospect of jail time.

;

;The far-right former army captain was already the subject of police probes before and during his four years in office. But his efforts to undermine faith in Brazil's voting system, which culminated in a Jan. 8 insurrection by thousands of his supporters in Brasilia, have only added to his problems.

;

;Bolsonaro has repeatedly denied breaking any laws, and calls allegations against him a witch hunt by his political opponents.

;

;Among the legal headaches now facing Bolsonaro:

;

;In June, Brazil's federal electoral court (TSE) ;barred Bolsonaro; from public office until 2030 for his conduct during last year's election. Five out of seven justices voted to convict him of abuse of power and misuse of the media when, in July 2022, he summoned ambassadors to vent unfounded claims of vulnerabilities in Brazil's electronic voting system.

;

;On Wednesday, a congressional probe which has been investigating the Jan. 8 insurrection by Bolsonaro's supporters recommended that he and several allies face charges of criminal association, political violence, disrupting the democratic order and an attempted coup d'état. The inquiry has no power to punish Bolsonaro or others, but can issue recommendations for them to face criminal or civil charges.

;

;Bolsonaro is still the subject of at least five criminal investigations led by the Supreme Court. They include alleged spreading of fake news about COVID-19 vaccines, leaking of details from a sealed federal police probe, interference in the federal police, propagation of online misinformation and masterminding the Jan. 8 riots in the capital.

;

;Bolsonaro and his former aides are also being investigated by the federal police for allegedly forging his vaccination records to travel to the United States. In May, police arrested former aide Mauro Cid for his alleged role in the scheme.

;

;Cid was also a central player in another alleged racket, in which Bolsonaro and his team are suspected of selling expensive jewels given to his administration by the Saudi government.

;

;Last month, after months in jail, Cid agreed to cooperate with the federal police and was freed from behind bars.

;

;In September, Brazilian media reported that Cid allegedly told police that Bolsonaro had sounded out commanders of the armed forces about a draft decree to overturn the election.
